message.content: We refer to a statistics textbook for help. Power is the probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis. It is affected by several factors, including sample size, effect size, and variance. Given that both studies have identical expected treatment effect sizes and variance, the larger sample size in Study B would yield a higher power. Therefore, the grant reviewer should fund Study B. The other options, such as the surgeon's reputation or multi-center design, are not relevant to power.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medical statistics for help. Larger sample size typically results in higher power, meaning the ability to detect a true effect if it exists. Therefore, Study B should be funded because it plans to enroll 300 patients compared to Study A's 50 patients per site. The surgeon's reputation and number of sites are not directly related to the power of the study.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Power is related to sample size, effect size, and variance. Study B has a larger sample size, therefore it has higher power than Study A, despite being double-blinded or single-blinded. The surgeon and number of centers are not relevant to power.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Power in hypothesis testing is determined by the sample size, significance level, and effect size. Study B has a much larger sample size, so it will have higher power even though it is double-blinded and has a sham surgery for the control group. The other options are not relevant to the power of the study.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The power of a study depends on sample size, treatment effect size, and variance. In this case, Study B has a larger sample size and the same expected treatment effect size and variance as Study A. Therefore, Study B will have higher power than Study A. The surgeon and multi-center enrollment are not relevant factors in determining power.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on statistics for help. Power is the probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis, and it is affected by sample size, effect size, and alpha level. Study B has a larger sample size, which generally increases power, so the reviewer should fund Study B. The other factors (renowned surgeon and multi-center trial) are not directly related to power.

We refer to resources on statistics for help. Power depends on sample size, effect size, and level of significance. Study B has a larger sample size, which increases the power. The other factors, such as the surgeon or center, are irrelevant to power. Therefore, the reviewer should fund Study B.

We refer to medical research articles for help. Sample size directly affects the power of a study. Although Study A has multiple centers and a highly regarded surgeon, Study B has a significantly larger sample size, which means it will have a higher power to detect a significant treatment effect. Therefore, the reviewer should fund Study B if they are interested only in which trial has the higher power.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on statistics for help. A larger sample size leads to increased power, so Study B should be funded because it plans to enroll 300 patients. The other factors mentioned have no bearing on the power of the study.

We refer to a tutorial article on biostatistics for help. Power is influenced by a variety of factors, including sample size, effect size, variance, alpha level, and study design. In this scenario, the only factor that differs between the two studies is sample size, with Study B enrolling 300 patients compared to Study A’s 250. Therefore, Study B should have higher power and be the one funded. The other factors listed (surgeon, multi-center vs. single-site, blinding) do not directly impact power.
